''[[Fact Hunt]]''; ''etc'' |influenced = |nationality = British |alma_mater = [[St Edmund Hall, Oxford]] |website = [http://thepublandlord.com/ www.thepublandlord.com] }} '''Alastair James Hay Murray''' (born 10 May 1968), is an [[England|English]] [[comedian]] and [[TV personality]]. He was listed in ''[[The Observer]]'' as one of the 50 funniest acts in British comedy.{{cite news |url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/features/story/0,11710,1101525,00.html |title=The A-Z of laughter |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=[[Guardian Unlimited]] |accessdate=27 December 2006 |location=London |date=7 December 2003}} In 2007, he was voted the 16th greatest stand-up comic on [[Channel 4]]'s 100 Greatest Stand-Ups. ==Early life and family background== Murray was born at 44 High Street South, [[Stewkley]], [[Buckinghamshire]], only son of [[Lieutenant Colonel|Lieut-Col.]] Ingram Bernard Hay Murray (a great-great-great-great-grandson of [[John Murray, 3rd Duke of Atholl|John, 3rd Duke of Atholl]], who married [[Charlotte Murray, Duchess of Atholl|Charlotte, Baroness Strange]]), by his wife Juliet Anne Thackeray, ''née'' Ritchie (a great-great-granddaughter of the celebrated novelist [[William Makepeace Thackeray]]).{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/comedy/3663518/Prime-time-gentlemen-please.html |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |title=Prime time gentlemen, please |first=Dominic |last=Cavendish |date=3 March 2007 |accessdate=23 April 2010}} His grandfather, the [[Ambassador|former British ambassador]] [[Ralph Murray|Sir Ralph Murray]],{{cite web |url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/a/604/al_murray |title=Al Murray's Biography |work=[[Chortle (website)|Chortle]] |accessdate=27 December 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070107210356/http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/a/604/al_murray |archivedate=7 January 2007 |deadurl=no}} was from [[Scottish people|Scottish]] aristocracy and married into the Kuenberg family, [[Imperial Count]]s,{{cite web|url=http://thepeerage.com/p2254.htm#i22531 |title=Mauricette Vladimira Marie Reichsgräfin Kuenburg |work=The Peerage.com |date= |accessdate=15 August 2013}} of the [[Holy Roman Empire]]. His patrilineal great-great-grandfather, [[George Murray (bishop of Rochester)|Dr George Murray]], was [[Bishop of Rochester]],{{cite book |title=Burke's Peerage}} while [[Edward Leigh|Sir Edward Leigh MP]] is his third cousin.{{cite book |title=Burke's Peerage |year=2003}} Al Murray is in [[Remainder (law)|remainder]] both to [[Peerage of England|English]] and [[Peerage of Scotland|Scottish]] [[hereditary peerage|peerage titles]], including the [[Baron Strange|barony of Strange]] and the [[Duke of Atholl|dukedom of Atholl]].{{cite web|url=http://www.debretts.com/shop/peerage-and-baronetage-2015.html |title=Debrett's Peerage & Baronetage |year=2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151113164040/http://www.debretts.com/shop/peerage-and-baronetage-2015.html |archivedate=13 November 2015 }} Murray was educated at [[Bedford School]], where he was head boy,{{Cite web |url=http://www.lovebedford.co.uk/towncentreguide/history-of-bedford.php |title=Harpurs Trust |work=BedfordBID}} and [[St Edmund Hall, Oxford]], where he read [[History|Modern History]].{{cite web |url=https://www.seh.ox.ac.uk/about-college/comedy-writers |title=Comedy Writers |work=St Edmund Hall}} At [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] he performed in the comedy group the [[The Oxford Revue|Oxford Revue]], in a show directed by [[Stewart Lee]], later an Honorary Fellow of St Edmund Hall.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/profiles/al_murray.shtml |title=Al Murray |publisher=BBC |work=BBC Comedy |accessdate=27 December 2006}} ==Personal life and campaigning== [[File:Twitter Joke Trial 1.jpg|thumb|Murray (left) with [[Twitter Joke Trial|Paul Chambers]] (centre) and [[Stephen Fry]] (right) outside the [[Royal Courts of Justice]] in London on 27 June 2012]] Murray married Amber Hargreaves in 2002. The couple, who have two daughters, Scarlett and Willow, separated in 2008.{{cite news |last=Irvine |first=Chris |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/3170833/Pub-Landlord-Al-Murray-breaks-up-with-wife.html |title=Al Murray breaks up with wife |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=10 October 2008 |accessdate=15 August 2013}} Murray is a keen [[cricket]] fan,{{cite web |url=http://www.lordstaverners.org/members/middlesex |title=Middlesex |work=Lords Taverners.org}} and was invited to attend a farewell lunch for the [[England cricket team]] before their departure for the [[2013–14 Ashes series]].{{cite web |url=http://www.lords.org/news/2013/october/long-room-goodbye-for-englands-ashes-squad/ |title=Long Room goodbye for England's Ashes squad |work=Lords.org |date=24 October 2013 |accessdate=26 August 2014}} Murray, together with [[Stephen Fry]], supported [[Twitter Joke Trial|Paul Chambers]]' High Court appeals after Chambers had been arrested for contravening the [[Communications Act 2003]] when a joke [[Twitter|tweet]] was regarded by police as "menacing" and a terrorist threat. An appeal against Chambers' conviction was successful.{{cite news |title=Robin Hood Airport tweet bomb joke man wins case|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-19009344|accessdate=9 September 2012|work=[[BBC News Online]] |date=27 July 2012}} In August 2014, Murray was one of 200 public figures who were signatories to a letter to ''[[The Guardian]]'' expressing their hope that Scotland would vote to remain part of the United Kingdom in September's [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014|referendum on that issue]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/aug/07/celebrities-open-letter-scotland-independence-full-text |title=Celebrities' open letter to Scotland – full text and list of signatories |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=7 August 2014 |accessdate=26 August 2014}} Murray was awarded an [[honorary degree]] (Hon MA) by the [[University of Bedfordshire]] in 2014,{{cite web |url=http://www.beds.ac.uk/news/2014/november/honorand-al-murray-praises-university-of-bedfordshire-diversity |title=Honorand Al Murray praises University of Bedfordshire diversity |work=University of Bedfordshire |date=21 November 2014}} and an honorary Doctor of Social Science (PhD) by the [[University of Wolverhampton]] in 2017.{{cite web |url=https://www.wlv.ac.uk/about-us/news-and-events/latest-news/2017/september-2017/honour-for-comedian-al-murray.php |title=Honour for comedian Al Murray |work=University of wolverhampton |date=22 September 2017}} ==Career in entertainment== Murray started out touring with fellow comedians including [[Harry Hill]] and [[Frank Skinner]]. He won the [[Perrier Award]] at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in 1999, after being nominated in 1996, 1997 and 1998.{{cite web |url=http://perriercomedyawards.com/past.htm |title=Perrier Comedy Awards |accessdate=27 December 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070711140401/http://perriercomedyawards.com/past.htm |archivedate=11 July 2007}} He started out with an act that involved sound-effect impressions, including guns, animals and a car boot. With this act he supported [[Jim Tavaré]] in Leeds in Winter 1992. In 1994–95, he was the drummer in the band Evangelista, the house band at Stewart Lee's and Simon Munnery's experimental [[Cluub Zarathustra]] in London.Evangelista were Pat Reid (vocals), Martin Ellis (guitar), Paul Ewart (bass) and Al Murray (drums). Reid and Ellis were at school together in Crosby, Liverpool. Reid was at Oxford with Murray. The line up included different bass players of which Paul Ewart was the longest lasting. [[Film maker]] Martin Pickles made a short film about the band in 2002. At this time the lead singer Reid described Murray as "he's still not a household name, but anyone who's into comedy knows who Al Murray is".Fall Apart: The Evangelista Story (2002), at 1.40. http://www.gmfilm.co.uk/fall_apart.html{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} This comment lead to great audience amusement when the film was screened at Pickles' 45th birthday in London in 2013. Half of the band can be seen in a video by Pickles: https://vimeo.com/77492045 Pickles also produced an Evangelista CD in 2003 featuring Murray. Contrary to the film the press release claimed the band was active 1992-1995. ===The Pub Landlord=== Murray's character is an English [[pub]]lican with [[Conservatism in the United Kingdom|conservative]] values and an animosity towards [[Germans]] and the [[French people|French]]; he will challenge the audience to name any [[List of sovereign states|country in the world]] before producing some plausible instance of [[United Kingdom|Britain]] bettering it. The character has a great love for the British 1970s [[rock band]] [[Queen (band)|Queen]], often getting musician(s) on his show to perform one of Queen's tunes in their own style. The character first appeared in 1994 during the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, in the show "Pub Internationale", with [[Harry Hill]] and Matthew Bradstock-Smith (who played "Little Alan" as well as the keyboards in Hill's Edinburgh, radio and TV shows). The show featured the "Pub Band", with Murray playing drums and compering. After trying out a character deemed not to have worked, at the opening show Murray suggested saying that the compere had not made it to the show and that the barman in the venue, the Pleasance Cabaret Bar, had offered to fill in. At the [[Edinburgh Festival]],{{cite web |url=https://edinburghfestival.list.co.uk/event/408504-al-murray-the-pub-landlords-summer-saloon/ |title=Al Murray - The Pub Landlord's Summer Saloon |work=edinburghfestival.list.co.uk}} Murray came up with "The Pub Landlord".[[Stewart Lee]] discusses whether all of Murray's audience realise the character is satirical in his book {{cite book|title=How I Escaped My Certain Fate |url=http://www.faber.co.uk/catalog/how-i-escaped-my-certain-fate/9780571254804 |publisher=Faber & Faber |location=London |year=2010 |pages=293–294 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029202728/http://www.faber.co.uk/catalog/how-i-escaped-my-certain-fate/9780571254804 |archivedate=29 October 2013 }} Murray made his first television appearances on ''[[Harry Hill (TV series)|Harry Hill]]'' in 1997 playing Harry's big brother Alan ("If it's too hard, I can't understand it!"), and subsequently featured in a short film, ''Pub Fiction.'' He made a brief appearance as the Pub Landlord in Series 2, Episode 6 of [[Lee and Herring]]'s ''[[This Morning with Richard Not Judy]]''. Murray's Pub Landlord theatre show, ''My Gaff, My Rules'' was [[short-list]]ed for an [[Laurence Olivier Award|Olivier Award]] in 2002.{{cite news |url=http://theenvelope.latimes.com/extras/lostmind/year/2001/2001_2002lo.htm |title=2001-2002 26th Laurence Olivier Awards |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=27 December 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061017162031/http://theenvelope.latimes.com/extras/lostmind/year/2001/2001_2002lo.htm |archivedate=17 October 2006 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The Pub Landlord is central focus of the television series ''[[Time Gentlemen Please]]'', as well as a number of other television appearances, including the ''An Audience with...'' strand. Subsequent theatre tours were: ''...And A Glass of White Wine for the Lady'' (another [[catchphrase]]) and ''Giving it Both Barrels''. The Pub Landlord has hosted several television programmes including ''[[Fact Hunt]]'', named after the fictional quiz machine of the same name from ''[[Time Gentlemen Please]]'',{{cite web |url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2005/03/19/316/pints_mean_prizes |title=Pints mean prizes |work=Chortle |accessdate=12 February 2007}} the [[BBC One]] show ''[[Live at the Apollo (TV series)|Live at the Apollo]]'' and [[UKTV]] channel [[Dave (TV channel)|Dave]]'s ''[[Al Murray's Compete for the Meat|Compete for the Meat]]'', which is co-hosted by [[Zöe Salmon]], with voice-overs from [[Jim Rosenthal]]. His [[chat show]] ''[[Al Murray's Happy Hour]]'' began airing 13 January 2007 on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]].{{cite news |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,14934-2498641_3,00.html |title=When Harry met Murray |work=[[Times Online]] |accessdate=7 January 2007 |location=London |first=Philippe |last=Naughton |subscription=yes}} The show has won a [http://www.britishcomedyawards.com/past-winners/2007.aspx British Comedy Award] for "Best New Entertainment Comedy".{{cite web|title=The British Comedy Awards Past Winners|url=http://www.britishcomedyawards.com/past-winners/2007.aspx|website=The British Comedy Awards|accessdate=26 May 2017}} Murray was the headliner of a July 2009 episode of ''[[Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow]]'', filmed at the [[Brighton Dome]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00lpkb7 |title=Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow |work=BBC One |date=6 April 2010}} From January 2006, the Pub Landlord filled in for [[Tim Lovejoy]] on [[Virgin Radio]] on Sunday afternoons, broadcasting his final show on 24 December 2006.{{cite web |url=http://www.virginradio.co.uk/djs_shows/djs/murray.html |title=Al Murray: Time Gentlemen Please |work=Virgin Radio |accessdate=12 February 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070208093623/http://www.virginradio.co.uk/djs_shows/djs/murray.html |archivedate=8 February 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} The Pub Landlord has written four books: ''The Pub Landlord's Book Of British Common Sense, The Pub Landlord's Think Yourself British, The Pub Landlord's Great British Quiz Book'', and ''Let's Re-Great Britain''. ===Other work=== As a teenager, Murray was a drummer in the "big band" at Bedford School,{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2007/oct/28/homes1 |title=What would you save if your house was burning down? |first=Laura |last=Potter |date=28 October 2007 |newspaper=The Guardian}} and also played [[percussion]] in the Bedfordshire County Youth Orchestra.{{cite web |url=http://www.fbym.org.uk/ensembles/youth-orchestra/ |title=County Youth Orchestra |work=Friends of Bedfordshire Youth Music}} He played drums on the music for "The Pub Landlord" television series and during an appearance on "Happy Hour" by [[Phil Collins]] they performed a [[duet]]. He also plays the drums for the rock cover band ''T-34'' and appeared at the [[Download 2010|Download Festival in 2010]], returning once again in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://downloadfestival.co.uk/2010/lineup/artist.aspx?AID=61b11377-42e0-4b00-8dec-5f8c8585a1a2&artist=T-34&lastfm=false|title=Download Festival - T34|accessdate=8 January 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110119101839/http://downloadfestival.co.uk/2010/lineup/artist.aspx?AID=61b11377-42e0-4b00-8dec-5f8c8585a1a2&artist=T-34&lastfm=false|archivedate=19 January 2011|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} In 2003, Murray appeared on an episode of the BBC's ''[[Time Commanders]]'' alongside [[Kate Silverton]], [[Raji James]] and [[Ricky Groves]]. In 2004, Murray appeared as a contestant in the first series of ''[[Hell's Kitchen (UK TV series)|Hell's Kitchen]]'', [[Gordon Ramsay]]'s cookery based reality show on [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]], and in 2005 appeared as a contestant on ''[[Comic Relief Does Fame Academy]]'' on [[BBC One]].{{cite news |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/fame/interviews/article.html?in_article_id=32751&in_page_id=11 |title=60 Seconds: Al Murray |newspaper=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] |publisher=[[DMG Media]] |accessdate=12 February 2007}} Murray presented ''[[Al Murray's Road to Berlin]]'' on the [[Discovery Channel]]. This was a series about the last phase of the [[Second World War]], taking him from the beaches of [[Normandy]], through [[Arnhem]] and up the [[Rhine]], ending in [[Berlin]]. In the series he drove around in a restored [[Willys MB|Willys Jeep]], and interviewed survivors from both sides of the war. In the episode about [[Operation Market Garden]] he parachuted, together with veterans, from an aircraft, to commemorate the battle.{{cite news |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/entertainment/filmandtv/s/233/233019_landlord_pulls_in_stars.html |title=Landlord pulls in stars |newspaper=[[Manchester Evening News]] |accessdate=12 February 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070125202648/http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/entertainment/filmandtv/s/233/233019_landlord_pulls_in_stars.html |archivedate=25 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite web |url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2005/07/13/777/putting_the_al_in_altitude |title=Putting the Al in altitude |work=Chortle |accessdate=12 February 2007}} Murray starred in ''[[Al Murray's Multiple Personality Disorder]]'', a sketch show, which aired in early 2009.{{cite news |url=http://www.chesterchronicle.co.uk/entertainment-chester/news-reviews/2008/12/18/al-murray-his-gaff-his-rules-59067-22497921 |title=Al Murray: His Gaff, His Rules |newspaper=[[Chester Chronicle]] |accessdate=26 December 2008}} In late 2010, Murray made a documentary on [[German culture]] for BBC Four ''Al Murray's German Adventure'' in which he presented a different side of the German nation from the one portrayed by "The Pub Landlord" character.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00wfy05 |title=Al Murray's German Adventure |work=BBC Four |date=10 April 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2013}} Also in 2010, Murray took part in "Star in a Reasonably Priced Car" on ''[[Top Gear (current format)|Top Gear]]'' with [[Jeremy Clarkson]].{{cite web |url=http://topgearspecials.com/al-murray-top-gear-episode/ |title=Al Murray Top Gear Episode |work=topgearspecials.com}} Murray serves as patron of the [[Cambodia]]n Children's Charity,{{cite web|url=http://www.camkids.org |title=The Cambodian Children's Charity ('CamKids') |work=Camkids.org |date=|accessdate=15 August 2013}} a development and relief charity for children in Cambodia.{{cite web |url=http://www.projectcambuild.org/background.php#camkids |title=CamBuild - Background |accessdate=26 October 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081210021935/http://projectcambuild.org/background.php#camkids |archivedate=10 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Murray became the host of the [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] show ''[[7 Day Sunday]]'' in March 2011, succeeding [[Chris Addison]], with the show later moving to Saturday (and associated name change). Murray invented his own potato crisps – branded "Steak and Al Pie" – as entered in a "crisp competition" hosted by [[Gary Lineker]], used to raise money for [[Comic Relief 2011|Comic Relief]].{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1354590/Comic-Relief-2011-Jimmy-Carr-Al-Murray-Gary-Lineker-crisp-flavour-battle.html |title=Do they taste funny? Jimmy Carr and Al Murray in crisp flavour battle for Comic Relief - with help from Gary Lineker |first=Jody |last=Thompson |date=7 February 2011 |newspaper=The Daily Mail}} The other flavours were "Jimmy Con Carne" ([[Jimmy Carr]]), "Stephen Fry-Up" ([[Stephen Fry]]) and "Frank Roast Dinner" ([[Frank Skinner]]). The winner was Stephen Fry-up at 27%, with Al's in 2nd with 25%. The other two got 24% each.{{cite web |url=http://www.talkingretail.com/products/product-news/stephen-fry-up-wins-walkers-clash-of-the-comics-for-red-nose-day |title=Stephen Fry Up wins Walkers Clash of the Comics for Red Nose Day |work=Talking Retail |date=18 March 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2013}} Murray sat in for [[Dermot O'Leary]] Saturday show on [[BBC Radio 2]] on 3 September 2011 and 26 November 2011. On 13 April and 26 July 2012 Murray guest-hosted the ''Kermode and Mayo's Film Review'' on [[BBC Radio 5 Live]]. On the latter, he exchanged places with critic [[Mark Kermode]] to review the comedy ''[[Ted (2012 film)|Ted]]''. On 8 December 2012 Murray appeared on the [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] special ''The McFly Show'' starring British pop band [[McFly]]. He played the band's [[drummer]] in character as "The Pub Landlord" while playing the drums with McFly for their cover version of the [[Queen (band)|Queen]] song "[[Don't Stop Me Now]]".{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/artists/al-murray/biography/ |title=About Al Murray |work=MTV.com}} On 1 January 2013 Murray was [[List of Today Programme Guest Editors|guest editor]] of ''[[Today (BBC Radio 4)|Today]]'' on [[BBC Radio 4]]. Since May 2013 Murray has hosted a show on [[Bauer Radio|Bauer]]'s digital radio station [[Planet Rock (radio station)|Planet Rock]] called ''Defender of the Planet Rock Tradition''.{{cite web|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2013/05/bauer-hires-al-murray-for-planet-rock/ |title=Bauer hires Al Murray for Planet Rock |work=Radio Today |date=7 August 2013 |accessdate=15 August 2013}} And he also had a special guest star appearance in the children's comedy ''[[Horrible Histories (2009 TV series)|Horrible Histories]]''. In 2014 he appeared as Jon Westmore in ''[[The Life of Rock with Brian Pern]]''. He also wrote and presented the TV documentary ''Al Murray's Great British Spy Movies'' on [[BBC Four]]. A fan of the rock band [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]], Murray contributed to the BBC's documentary about the band ''[[Genesis: Together and Apart]]''.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/tv-and-radio-reviews/11139604/Genesis-Together-and-Apart-review-an-entertaining-riff.html |title=Genesis: Together and Apart, review: 'an entertaining riff' |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |first=Ceri |last=Radford |date=4 October 2014 |accessdate=12 July 2015}} In September 2015 Murray co-founded the British Drum Company.{{cite web |url=http://www.britishdrumco.com/our-story|title=About British Drum Co|author= |date=6 January 2017|website=British Drum Co}} In August 2016 and March 2017 Murray sat in for [[Steve Wright (DJ)|Steve Wright]] on his [[Steve Wright in the Afternoon]] show on [[BBC Radio 2]]. In April 2016, Murray played [[Nick Bottom]] in ''Shakespeare Live'', a celebration of 400 years of Shakespeare, opposite [[Judi Dench]] as Titania.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-36111591 |title=Dame Judi leads Shakespeare Day gala finale |date=24 April 2016 |work=BBC News Online}} Murray participated in series three of the comedy challenge show ''[[Taskmaster (TV series)|Taskmaster]]'', which aired on [[Dave (TV channel)|Dave]] in 2017.{{cite web |url=https://www.comedy.co.uk/tv/news/2080/taskmaster_series_3_lineup|title=Taskmaster Series 3 line-up revealed |author= |date=16 April 2016 |website=British Comedy Guide}} ==Parliamentary candidacy== On 14 January 2015, Murray announced the formation of the Free United Kingdom Party (FUKP){{cite web |url=http://www.kentonline.co.uk/thanet/news/the-pub-landlord-visits-thanet-31200/ |title=Pub Landlord Al Murray visits Thanet as FUKP leader |first=James |last=Rose |date=3 February 2015 |work=Kent Online}} and declared his candidacy, deploying his Pub Landlord persona, for the [[Electoral district|seat]] of [[South Thanet (UK Parliament constituency)|South Thanet]]{{cite web |url=https://www.theparliamentmagazine.eu/articles/special-report/al-murrays-eurozone-crisis-solution-europe-goes-pound |title=Al Murray's eurozone crisis solution: 'Europe goes on the pound' |first=Rajnish |last=Singh |date=22 January 2015 |work=[[The Parliament Magazine]]}} running against [[UKIP]] leader [[Nigel Farage]], as [[Prospective parliamentary candidate|parliamentary candidate]] in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]].{{cite web |title=Al Murray to stand against UKIP's Nigel Farage |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-kent-30819779 |author=|date=14 January 2015 |website=BBC News Online |accessdate=14 January 2015}}{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tADgYkAfXro |title=The Guv's common sense message to the UK |author=almurray |date=14 January 2015 |work=YouTube}} Murray’s agent, Dan Lloyd, told the [[BBC]]: "it's definitely happening". The [[List of frivolous political parties|party]]'s logo is an upside-down [[pound sign]],{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2910053/Pints-penny-fruit-based-drinks-ladies-Pub-Landlord-Al-Murray-sets-pitch-Parliament-standing-against-Nigel-Farage.html |title=Pints for a penny and some Poles to brick up the Chunnel: Pub Landlord Al Murray sets out his FUKP pitch for Parliament... standing AGAINST Nigel Farage in Thanet |first=Tom |last=McTague |work=[[MailOnline]] |date=14 January 2015}} not dissimilar to UKIP’s purple and gold pound sign.{{cite news |title=Last orders for Nigel Farage? Pub Landlord takes on Ukip |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/jan/14/nigel-farage-pub-landlord-al-murray |first=Frances |last=Perraudin |date=14 January 2015 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=14 January 2015}} Murray said: “it seems to me that the UK is ready for a bloke waving a pint around, offering common sense solutions", adding: “let it be known that like many of the parliamentary hopefuls in the forthcoming election, I have no idea where [[South Thanet]] is – but did that stop [[Margaret Thatcher]] from saving the [[Falkland Islands]]? No!”{{cite news |title=Watch: Al Murray Pub Landlord to take on Nigel Farage |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/general-election-2015/11345488/Watch-Al-Murray-Pub-Landlord-to-take-on-Nigel-Farage.html |author= |date=14 January 2015 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=14 January 2015}} Farage appeared to welcome his new opponent on [[Twitter]], saying "the more, the merrier", and a spokesperson for the UKIP [[Member of The European Parliament|MEP]] said: “at last, serious competition in the constituency”.{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1407841/al-murray-pub-landlord-to-run-against-farage |title=Al Murray Pub Landlord To Run Against Farage |date=14 January 2015 |work=Sky News}} The [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] candidate, [[Craig Mackinlay]], said he enjoyed Murray's video and his proclamations but was not worried that the comedian would split the anti-UKIP vote.{{cite journal |url=http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/steerpike/2015/01/al-murray-in-twitter-spat-with-ukip-mep/ |title=Al Murray in Twitter spat with Ukip MEP |author=Steerpike |journal=[[The Spectator]] |date=15 January 2015}} Finally, the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] candidate, Will Scobie, insisted it was "always good to have people putting their names forward to stand" and that Murray would "certainly make things interesting". When nominations for South Thanet were released on 9 April 2015, it was confirmed that Murray would appear on the ballot paper with no description, rather than his FUKP name and emblem.{{cite web|url=http://thanet.gov.uk/your-services/elections-and-voting/parliamentary-election-2015/south-thanet/ |title=Election of a Member of Parliament: South Thanet Constituency |work=Thanet District Council |accessdate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150507183430/http://thanet.gov.uk/your-services/elections-and-voting/parliamentary-election-2015/south-thanet |archivedate=7 May 2015 |df=dmy }}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/pub-landlord-al-murray-uses-fire-engine-to-launch-fukp-election-campaign-for-south-thanet-10164069.html |title=Pub Landlord Al Murray uses fire engine to launch FUKP election campaign for South Thanet |first=Helen |last=Nianias |date=9 April 2015 |newspaper=The Independent}}{{cite news |url=http://www.thanetgazette.co.uk/Z-elections-Thanet/story-26309832-detail/story.html |title=An A to Z of the elections in Thanet |first=Kathy |last=Bailes |date=9 April 2015 |newspaper=Isle of Thanet Gazette |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150703023306/http://www.thanetgazette.co.uk/Z-elections-Thanet/story-26309832-detail/story.html |archivedate=3 July 2015}} The results of the election were announced on 8 May, revealing that Murray garnered 318 votes. This number of votes was higher than the average votes received by candidates from, amongst others, the Communist, Socialist and BNP parties.{{cite news |last=Nianias |first=Helen |title=It's not just Nigel Farage: Al Murray the Pub Landlord loses South Thanet bid despite patriotic pledges |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/its-not-just-nigel-farage-al-murray-the-pub-landlord-loses-south-thanet-bid-despite-patriotic-pledges-10235430.html |accessdate=11 June 2015|newspaper=The Independent|date=8 May 2015}}{{Failed verification|date=February 2016}} When it was announced that Farage had failed to get elected, coming second in the poll to the Conservative candidate [[Craig Mackinlay]], Murray's reaction – feigning shock and clapping on stage – garnered widespread media attention.{{cite news |last=Connor |first=Laura |title=Watch Al Murray's priceless reaction as Ukip leader Nigel Farage is beaten by Tories in his target seat |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/politics/watch-al-murrays-priceless-reaction-5660841 |accessdate=11 May 2015 |newspaper=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] |date=8 May 2015}} Speaking to the media during the vote count, Murray invited Farage to a drink in his pub to drown his sorrow at losing.{{cite news |title=Nigel Farage can drown his sorrows in my pub should he lose, says Al Murray - video |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/video/2015/may/08/nigel-farage-can-drown-sorrows-my-pub-should-lose-south-thanet-al-murray |accessdate=11 May 2015 |agency=[[ITN]] |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=8 May 2015}} ==Stand-up DVDs== {| class="wikitable" |- !
